snippet: A chemistry professor argues that humanities degrees may be more important for tomorrow's job market than is generally believed.
abstract: A chemistry professor argues that humanities degrees may be more important for tomorrow's job market than is generally believed.
lead_paragraph: We've written several blog posts about the small share of American college students majoring in the so-called STEM fields -- science, technology, engineering and mathematics -- with the implicit premise that more bachelor's degrees in technical fields is both desirable on a macroeconomic level and is professionally advantageous at the individual worker level. A former dean of an engineering school suggests that thinking may be wrong.

headline.main: A Reason to Major in the Humanities
